lines.text: If you're a chicken, you can fool people about your feathers. But when you start laying eggs all over the place, they know you're a chicken.
It's the first of July, Mrs. McNulty.
Already? Gee, June flied in a hurry. Isn't it?
So did May and April. The bank can't wait any longer.
You don't know what it was like working with her yesterday. I felt like I was 21 again.
Oh Malarky
Look wiseguy, I didn't feel like I was 21 when I was 21.
When you stop worrying, you'll be dead.
When you've been brought up in a half a dozen embassies, the little princes and little dukes and little diplomats, bowing from the waist and kissing your hand, what do you think you dream about?
What?
You dream of meeting a man.
I married a stranger!
Everybody marries a stranger.

[speaking of 'the aberrations that sometime overtake the male sex']
Why I once knew a brigadier general who couldn't be left alone with a French telephone!
Never eat standing up, and never cook sittin' down.
Well, who stole the meat outta her sandwich?

[Preparing a sleeping pill for her daughter, Maggie]
Now you just swallow one of these pills, and you'll sleep for eight solid hours... Here. You know who gave them to me? I wouldn't want it known... Mussolini! He was a terrible man, but he ate well, and he slept well.
Junior Kalinger? Oh, he's OK.
Oh, go on, I've stepped on better things.
If your father were alive, he'd turn over in his grave!

[to Val, the newlywed]
This is your mating season, you're entitled to be alone.
Ma, when will you get over that I'm not six years old anymore?
Never. Six is plenty big for a boy to be.
